question: Don Francesco. You murdered my husband, because he would not bend. And his oldest son Paolo, because he swore revenge. But Vitone is only nine, and dumb-witted. He never speaks.
answer: I'm not afraid of his words.

question: He is weak.
answer: He will grow strong.

question: The child cannot harm you.
answer: He will be a man, and then he will come for revenge.

question: I will not shut my mouth, and keep your Goddamn hands off of me!
answer: Honey! Wait a minute; let's go for a drive.

question: I just had a drive; besides, I want to see my brother-in-law Michael.
answer: Yeah, but I don't want him to see you.

question: What beats me, is how you guys could be brothers. You musta been your Mother's rotten egg. Young man, young man...thank you, young man. Yes, you saw me in the movies, Good Humor man, and yes, I had more off than my shoes!
answer: Goddamn bitch.

question: Relax, Freddie honey. Come dance with me.
answer: Listen, Michael's got a lot of nice people here. Friends of Kay's. He'll never forgive me if you ruin his party.

question: I hate to see you cringe in front of him. How come you're so scared of your own kid brother?
answer: He's the head of the family.

question: Mama...Mama! Here I am!
answer: Constanzia. We expected you last week; we sent the car to pick you up at the airport last week.

question: I know, it was chaos; but anyway, here I am one week late. This is for my Mama. You remember Merle?
answer: Yes, thank you.

question: How are the kids?
answer: Well, thank you, they asked for you all week.

question: I got surprises for everybody!
answer: Bought at the airport.

question: This is swell. Where's Michael? I've got things to get straight with him and I can't wait on line.
answer: You go see your children first, and then you wait to see your brother like everybody else.

question: Hey, kid! You got any red wine? Forget it... Fredo! Sonuvabitch. You look great.
answer: Who's that? Pentangeli? Frankie "Five-Angels"...thought you were never coming West.

question: Gotta check up on my boys. Hey, what's with the food? Some kid in a white jacket brings me a ritz cracker with some chopped liver. 'Canapes,' he says. I say, 'Can a peas, my ass, that's a ritz cracker with chopped liver.' Go get me a salami sandwich and a glass of wine or I'll send you and your white jacket to the dry cleaners!
answer: Gee, Frankie, it's good to see you. Reminds me of old times.

question: You remember Willy Cicci, don't you, Freddie? We was all together with the old man Clemenza in Brooklyn... before...uh...
answer: We were all upset about that.

question: That's what I'm here to talk to your brother about. What's with him, I got to get a letter of introduction to have a 'sitdown'?
answer: C'mon, I see what I can do.

question: Not now...
answer: Francesca is my oldest brother's daughter. He died many years ago, and ever since I've felt much more of a father than an uncle. I love her very much. I'm pleased and impressed that you had the thought to come to me before going on with your plans. It shows me that you're a considerate man, and will be good to her. What are you studying in college? How will Fine Arts support your new wife? Never be embarrassed by your wealth. This recent contempt for money is still another trick of the rich to keep the poor without it. Of course I give you my blessing. Let's set the wedding soon...it will be my pleasure to give the bride away. ...and take a few courses in Business Administration just to be on the safe side! Make her dowry impressive. He comes from a family who still thinks an Italian bride goes barefoot.

question: His name is Fred Vincent. He owns a small pizza parlor in Buffalo... ...American wife and two small kids. We traced him and found that he's in the country illegally, from Sicily... ...came over around 1956. Sponsored by the Barzini Family.
answer: It's him. Fabrizzio. Revenge is a dish that tastes best when it's cold.

question: How do you want me to handle it?
answer: Later. Tom?

question: Later. Tom?
answer: I've cleared it through the Senator's chief aide, a man named Turnbull. Turnbull's a heavy gambler, and into us for over a hundred grand, so I figure his information is reliable. The Senator can be set up; but he thinks of himself as a clean politician. So it's got to be on terms he can live with I'm sorry; of course, you know that.

question: Two-thirty. That gives me time to see my boy.
answer: Connie's outside. I promised; she said it was urgent.

question: The ink on your divorce isn't dry. Your children see you on weekends; your oldest boy, Michael Francis... was in some trouble with the Reno police over some petty theft that you don't even know about.
answer: Michael...

question: You fly around the world with lazy young men who don't have any love for you, and use you like a whore.
answer: You're not my father!

question: Then why do you come to me?
answer: Because I need MONEY!

question: Connie, I want to be reasonable with you. You have a house here, with us. You can live here with your kids...and you won't be deprived of anything. I don't know much about Merle; I don't know what he does for a living; what he lives on. Why don't you tell him marriage is really out of the question; and that you can't see him any more. He'll understand. But if you disobey me, and marry this pimp...it would disappoint me.
answer: It was my father's money; and I'm entitled to what I need. Where is Tom Hagen?

question: Just tell Rocco I'm waiting.
answer: I just left our friend in Miami.

question: How is his health?
answer: Not good.

question: Is there anything I can do; anything I can send?
answer: He appreciates your concern, Michael, and your respect. The hotel's registered owners are one Jacob Lawrence, and Sidney Barclay, both Beverly Hills attorneys. In reality it's split between the Old Lakeville Road Group from Cleveland, and our friend in Miami. He takes care of others outside the country, you know who I mean. Meyer Klingman runs the store, and does all right, but I've been instructed to tell you, that if you move him out, our friend in Miami will go along with you.

question: He's very kind, tell him it's appreciated. I'm sure it will be profitable all the way around.
answer: He always makes money for his partners. One by one, our old friends are gone. Death, natural or not, prison, deported. Our friend in Miami is the only one left, because he always made money for his partners.

question: Anthony, Daddy's busy.
answer: This is my boy, and my wife. Mr. John Ola of Miami.

question: I'm sorry, Michael. Senator Geary's here, and Mr. and Mrs. Barrett wanted to thank you before they left. Won't you join us, Mr. Ola?
answer: Mr. Ola's just leaving, Kay. Please tell the Senator I won't be a minute. Kay.

question: He doesn't want my help any more. He doesn't need it.
answer: We don't know that's true, he never said that.

question: I can feel it in the way he talks to me. Just now when Johnny Ola showed up, he asked me to leave them alone. Ola is Hyman Roth's Sicilian contact. I was on the inside of ten, twenty meetings with him. But today Mike asked me to leave, like an outsider.
answer: Talk to him. Tell him how you feel.

question: It's as though he blames me for the ground the family lost when I was Consigliere to Sonny. I love Michael, I want to help him, be close to him. I don't want to end up a third string lawyer making property settlements for the hotels.
answer: We have a little time now.

question: ...my thanks, and the thanks of the young people of the State of Nevada, for this most impressive endowment... ...made to the University in the name of Anthony Vito Corleone. Thank you, Mr. and Mrs. Michael Corleone. Where can we meet alone?
answer: Find Hagen. It was very kind of you to come to my home on this occasion, Senator. My wife has been very concerned with making a good impression on the people who are our neighbors, and your appearance here has made her very happy. If I can ever perform a service for you, you only have to ask. My lawyer, Tom Hagen. He arranged this all through your man Turnbull.

question: I thought we would meet alone.
answer: I trust these men with my life. They are my right arms; I cannot insult them by sending them away.

question: Some water. Alright, Corleone. I'm going to be very frank with you. Maybe more frank than any man in my position has ever spoken to you before. The Corleone family controls two major hotels in Vegas; one in Reno. The licenses were grandfathered in, so you had no difficulties with the Gaming Commission. But I have the idea from sources... ...that you're planning to move in on the Tropicana. In another week or so you'll move Klingman out, which leaves you with only one technicality. The license, which is now in Klingman's name.
answer: Turnbull is a good man.

question: Let's forget the bullshit, I don't want to stay here any longer than I have to. You can have the license for two hundred and fifty thousand in cash, plus a monthly fee equal to five percent of the gross... ...of all three Corleone hotels.
answer: Senator Geary, I speak to you as a businessman who has made a large investment in your state. I have made that state my home; plan to raise my children here. The license fee from the Gambling Commission costs one thousand dollars; why would I ever consider paying more?

question: Yeah, the kid and me talked Sicilian. A one-way conversation! Sure, Pete Clemenza died of a heart attack, but the Rosato Brothers gave it to him.
answer: We were all heartbroken at the news; but that wasn't cause to start a war.

question: Okay, now it's my family in Brooklyn; and I wanna keep up Clemenza's loyalty to you. But how can I run my family with you challenging my every move? You're too far from the street, Mike, the only way to reason with the Rosato Brothers is to whack 'em and whack 'em fast.
answer: You were unfair with them.

question: Says who?
answer: Clemenza promised Rosato three territories in the Bronx after he died, and then you took over and welched.

question: Clemenza promised them nothing, he hated the sonsuvbitches.
answer: They feel cheated.

question: Michael, you're sitting up here in the Sierra Mountains with champagne cocktails making judgment on the way I run my family.
answer: Your family still carries the name Corleone, and you will run it like a Corleone!

question: And while I feed my family in New York, you put the knife in my back in Miami.
answer: Frankie, you're a good old man, and you've been loyal to my Father for years...so I hope you can explain what you mean.

question: The Rosatos are running crazy; taking hostages, spitting in my face, because they're backed by the Jew in Miami.
answer: I know. That's why I want you to be fair with them.

question: How can you be fair with animals? They recruit niggers and spicks; they do violence in their own Grandmother's neighborhoods. And everything is dope and whores; the gambling is left to last. Let me run my family without you on my back. I want them taken care of.
answer: No. There are things that I have planned with Hyman Roth. I don't want them disturbed.

question: You give your loyalty to a Jew over your own blood.
answer: Frankie, you know my father respected Roth, did business with him.

question: I wanta dance...whatsa matter with that?
answer: Dancing is alright; you're falling on the floor.

question: Whatsamatter, you don't want me to dance with him 'cause he's a man!
answer: Deanna, I'm going to belt you right in the mouth!

question: Forget it, just go take care of her. How's the baby?
answer: Sleeping inside me.

question: Does it feel like a boy?
answer: Yes, Michael, it does.

question: I'm sorry about some of the people I had to see today. It was bad timing... but it couldn't be helped.
answer: It made me think of what you told me once. In five years, the Corleone family will be completely legitimate. That was seven years ago.

question: Are you Klingman?
answer: Who's asking?

question: Where can we talk?
answer: Right here.

question: I represent the interests of the Corleone family. We make the invitation to you to tie up your affairs and be out of the hotel by Monday morning.
answer: Who do you think you're talking to?

question: You said you were Klingman.
answer: You don't come in here, talk to an owner in Las Vegas like that.

question: You missed my point; you are no longer an owner.
answer: Get out of my hotel. Boys, get him out of here.

question: I know what you are thinking, Vitone, but you don't understand yet how things are. Fanucci is of the Black Hand. Everyone in the neighborhood pays him, even my father.
answer: He's an Italian?

question: A pig of a Neaponitan.
answer: Why? Why does he bother other Italians?

question: Because he knows them; he knows they have no one to protect them. Vitone? What do you think of my angel?
answer: Beautiful.

question: Beautiful.
answer: For you, she is beautiful. For me, there is only my wife!

question: I bet you can't guess what happened?
answer: What?

question: Some guys from Ninth Avenue jumped Fanucci today; slit his throat from ear to ear.
answer: No, I didn't know. Is he dead?

question: Nah. Those guys aren't murderers. They wanted to scare him, that's all. Make him look bad.
answer: In Sicily, when you attack a man, you had better finish him.

question: I wish they had. He takes fifty dollars a week from my father's cash drawer. But you can't kill a man like Fanucci.
answer: Why?

question: We are all well. And you must give him my job. You have been kind to me since I was a boy; taken care of me, and been as a father. I will always be grateful to you. Thank you. No...please understand...I cannot accept.
answer: Hey Paisan! Hold this for me until I ask for it. Hurry up! Do you have my goods still? Did you look inside? I'm not interested in things that don't concern me. I have a friend who has a fine rug. Maybe your wife would like it.

question: We have no money for a rug.
answer: No. He would give it away. I know how to repay a consideration.

question: She would like it. Your friend lives in a fine building.
answer: Oh yes, the very best. Ah, he's not at home. Oh, well, he wouldn't mind. A little help. Good, you waited for us.

question: Ahhh, young fellow. People tell me you're rich, you and your two friends. Yet, you don't show enough respect to send a few dresses to my home. You know I have three daughters. This is my neighborhood. You and your friends have to show me a little respect, ah? This truck you hijacked was in my neighborhood. You should let me wet my beak a little. I understand each of you cleared around six hundred dollars. I expect two hundred dollars for my protection and I'll forget the insult. After all, young people don't know the courtesies due a man like myself. Otherwise the police will come to see you and your wife and children will be dishonored and destitute. Of course, if my information as to your gains is incorrect, I'll dip my beak just a little. Just a little, but no less than one hundred dollars, and don't try to deceive me, eh paisan?
answer: My two friends have my share of the money. I'll have to speak to them after we deliver these to the wholesaler.

question: You tell your friends I expect them to let me wet my beak in the same manner. Don't be afraid to tell them. Clemenza and I know each other well, he understands these things. Let yourself be guided by him. He has more experience in these matters.
answer: You must understand, this is all new to me...

question: I understand...
answer: But thank you for speaking to me as a Godfather.

question: Do you think he'd be satisfied with the two hundred dollars? I think he would.
answer: That scar-faced bastard will find out what we got from the wholesaler. He won't take a dime less than three hundred dollars.

question: What if we don't pay?
answer: You know his friends...real animals. And his connections with the police. Sure he'd like us to tell him our plans so he can set us up for the cops and earn their gratitude. Then they would owe him a favor; that's how he operates. We'll have to pay. Three hundred, are we agreed?

question: What can we do?
answer: They say Fanucci has a license from Maranzalla himself to work this neighborhood.

question: Can't you sleep? Are you alright?
answer: Yes.

question: Did you like your party?
answer: I got lots of presents.

question: Do you like them?
answer: I didn't know the people who gave them to me.

question: They were friends.
answer: Did you see my present for you?

question: No, where is it?
answer: On your pillow.

question: I'm leaving very early tomorrow, before you wake up.
answer: I know. How long will you be gone?

question: Just a few days.
answer: Will you take me?

question: I can't.
answer: Why do you have to go?

question: To do business.
answer: I can help you.

question: Go with the kids.
answer: They're still on the property. Maybe you better stay inside.

question: Keep them alive.
answer: We'll try.

question: It's important. It will be all right. We were lucky.
answer: Your family all seem to be okay in the other houses; your Mother's still sleeping.

question: And?
answer: No sign of them yet; but they're still on the Estate.

question: Have Tom Hagen meet me in the Harbor House. Sit down, Tom. There's a lot I can't tell you, Tom. I know that's upset you in the past; and you've felt that it was because of some lack of trust or confidence. But it is because I do trust you that I've kept so much secret from you. It's precisely that at this moment, you are the only one that I can completely trust. In time, you'll understand everything.
answer: But your people... Neri... Rocco; you don't think...

question: No, I have confidence in their loyalty... but this is life and death, and Tom, you are my brother.
answer: Mikey, I hoped...

question: I've prepared this; have had it for over a month. It won't explain everything; but indicates where I will be, so in a sense, it is my life. Also, there are three tasks that must be executed immediately. Pop would have given those to Luca -- You knew Pop as well as anyone, act as though you were him. It discusses Kay as well; that will be the most difficult. The men who tried to kill me tonight, will never leave the estate.
answer: Will we...be able to get who ordered it out of them?

question: I don't think so. Unless I'm very wrong...they're already dead. Killed by someone inside...very frightened that they botched it. That's why I am going to disappear in a few minutes, and leave everything to you.
answer: But if you're wrong...

question: If I'm wrong... ...I don't think I'm wrong. Yes. Fish them out.
answer: Get rid of the bodies. Tomorrow morning I want a report made to the local police, and paper, that some explosives we keep on the property were accidentally ignited.

question: Get rid of the bodies. Tomorrow morning I want a report made to the local police, and paper, that some explosives we keep on the property were accidentally ignited.
answer: All right, Mr. Hagen, you've got ten minutes. ...and the tape will be running.

question: Actually, I've come with good news; the Corleone family has done you a favor.
answer: What the hell are you talking about?

question: We know you're a busy man, with plenty of enemies -- we saw the opportunity to do you a favor, and we did. No strings.
answer: No strings.

question: You know there's a Senate Investigating Committee recently set up; we thought it would be unfortunate if they were to trace anything though-provoking to your name.
answer: No one can trace anything to me; I pride myself on that.

question: Do you gamble?
answer: A little; what's so thought- provoking about that?

question: Do you owe markers?
answer: Maybe two, three thousand dollars.

question: The Corleone family has paid them off for you...as an expression of our esteem.
answer: There's thirty grand worth of paid off markers -- I never owed that much.

question: Our mistake. But what does it matter; it was our money. We don't even expect thanks.
answer: You paid off thirty grand I never owed.

question: We'll keep it quiet; the people who know are trustworthy...the Committee needn't find out.
answer: And what's the price of their not finding out.

question: Simple. Be friendly like us. Not hostile.
answer: Thanks...friend.

question: Yes. I'm going to the market. Whose orders are these?
answer: Kay. I wanted to explain this myself... I had business in Carson City. It's Michael's request...for your safety. We can send out for anything you need.

question: I'm supposed to stay in my house.
answer: Within the compound will be fine.

question: I was supposed to take the children to New England next week.
answer: That's off now.

question: I'm going to see my parents.
answer: Kay, Michael didn't tell me a lot; and what he did tell me, I can't repeat. But the responsibility for you and the kids was the most important thing he left me with.

question: How long does this go on?
answer: I don't know. I'm sorry, Kay...

question: Am I a prisoner?
answer: That's not the way we look at it.

question: You'll wait in the car.
answer: I'm just going to make lunch. How about a tuna fish sandwich?

question: Thank you, Mrs. Roth.
answer: Hyman...HYMAN, your friend is here. Why don't you go right upstairs, Mr. Paul?

question: Fine.
answer: I'll give a yell when lunch is ready.

question: Sit down, this is almost over. You follow the baseball games?
answer: Not for a few years.

question: I like sporting events -- I really enjoy watching them in the afternoon. One of the things I love about this country. I loved baseball ever since Arnold Rothstein fixed the World Series of 1919...I heard you had some trouble.
answer: Yes.

question: What a mistake; people behaving like that, with guns. It was my understanding we left all that behind. But, let me tell you, the important thing is that you're all right. Good health is the most important thing; more than success; more than power; more than money.
answer: The incident of the other night is a nuisance that I can take care of. I came to you because I want nothing to affect our agreement; I wanted to clear everything I'm going to do with you, just in case.

question: You're a considerate young man.
answer: You're a great man, Mr. Roth, I have much to learn from you.

question: However I can help you...
answer: The Rosato Brothers have performed services for you in the past; I understand that they are under your protection.

question: We do favors for each other...
answer: Technically, they are still under the Clemenza wing of the Corleone Family, now run by Frankie Pentangeli. After Clemenza died, the Rosatos wanted territory of their own. Pentangeli refused, and came to me, asking for permission to eliminate them. I, of course, knew of their relationship with you, and in gratitude for your help with the Tropicana matter, turned him down. Pentangeli was furious, and paid one hundred and fifty thousand dollars to have me killed. I was lucky and he was stupid. I'll visit him soon. The important thing is that nothing jeopardize our plans, yours and mine. This thing of ours, that we will build.

question: Nothing is more important.
answer: Pentangeli is a dead man; do you object?

question: It's always bad for business; but you have no choice.
answer: Then it's done. I must choose his replacement

question: Rosato, where's your brother?
answer: Sitting right behind you.

question: He don't want to talk?
answer: We worked it all out beforehand.

question: Are we going to eat or what?
answer: Sure, on me. I got Diner's Club.

question: Forget it; I'm suddenly without an appetite. You're making big trouble, Carmine.
answer: You weren't straight with us, Frankie, what else could we do?

question: We could have talked first, saved a lot of running around.
answer: You wasn't listening, you didn't want to talk.

question: Don't I look like I'm listening?
answer: We want Brooklyn one hundred percent. No more taxes to you. We want to be only loosely connected with your family -- sort of a under-family all of our own. Then we can act on all internal matters without talking. Also we want you to inform Michael Corleone that we can deal directly with him.

question: I'm a little hungry, maybe I'll order something. Joe. Get me some bracciole or something. And pay cash. And in return for these concessions, what do you do for me?
answer: We will release the hostages, number one. Number two, we're here for you to count on when you need us. We're independent, but we're here if you need us. In general, we'll cooperate with you and your businesses, and you in turn will cooperate with us. Pari persu.

question: Pari Persu; what the fuck is Pari persu...?
answer: My lawyer went over this beforehand.

question: What assurances do I have that there will be no more kidnapping, no more hits?
answer: The same assurance we got from you.

question: What if I say shove it?
answer: Then Carmine Fucillo and Tony Blue DeRosa will need to be fitted for slabs.

question: You want a war?
answer: We got no choice.

question: You know if there's a way I'll go to the commission and the commission will side with me. That puts me and the other New York families against you.
answer: We got friends in the commission.

question: I'm talking about Italians!
answer: What about Michael Corleone?

question: He supports me.
answer: Maybe, yes... maybe no.

question: You drove old Pete Clemenza to his grave, Carmine; you and your brother. Turning on him; trouble in his territories -- you and your demands. I hold you responsible, just as though you shot him in the head. And I ain't gonna let that go for long!
answer: Hey, Five-Angels...

question: Nobody I hate calls me Five-Angels to my face! What's up? What's this? One Michael Corleone...Dove? Don Corleone, I wish you let me know you was coming. We could have prepared something for you.
answer: I didn't want you to know I was coming. You heard what happened in my home?

question: Michael, yes, we was all relieved...
answer: In my home! In the same room where my wife was sleeping; where my children come in their pajamas, and play with their toys. I want you to help me take my revenge.

question: Michael, anything. What is it I can do for you?
answer: I want you to settle these troubles with the Rosato Brothers.

question: I was just going to contact you, Michael; we just had a 'sit-down' - in fact, I just come from there.
answer: I want you to settle on their terms.

question: Mike, I don't understand. Don't ask me to do that.
answer: Trust me; do as I ask.

question: It would be the beginning of the end for my family. How can I keep all my other territories in like if I let two wise-guys stand up and demand this and that, and then give it to them?
answer: Frankie...do you respect me? Do I have your loyalty?

question: Always... But sometimes I don't understand. I know I'll never have your kind of brains, in big deals. But Mike, this is a street thing. And Hyman Roth in Miami is behind the Rosato Brothers.
answer: I know.

question: Then why do you want me to lay down to them?
answer: Frankie, Roth tried to have me killed. I'm sure it was him, but I don't know yet why.

question: Jesus Christ, Michael, then let's hit 'em now, while we still got the muscle.
answer: This was my father's old study. When I was a kid, we had to be quiet when we played near here. When I was older, I learned many things from him here. I was happy that this house never went to strangers; first Clemenza took it over, and then you. My father taught me, in this room, never to act until you know everything that's behind things. Never. If Hyman Roth sees that I interceded with you in the Rosato Brothers' favor, he'll think his relationship with me is still sound. I'm going somewhere to meet him tomorrow. We have friends in some very important business that we're making. Do this for me; you make the peace with the Rosato Brothers on their terms. Let the word out that I forced you; you're not happy wit hit, but acquiesced, just because of me. It will get back to Hyman Roth. Do this, Frankie. You can trust me.

question: Sure, Mike. I'll go along.
answer: Good.

question: Fifteen percent skim?
answer: Twenty-five this time.

question: It might show.
answer: Mike wants it.

question: We've never sent this much with one courier.
answer: Your plans are a little different this time. You skip Miami, and go straight to Geneva. It's to be deposited to this number. And it's got to be there by Monday morning, no slip-up.

question: Let them count.
answer: What's up?

question: No questions.
answer: I got to ask questions, Tom, there's three million dollars cash in that pouch; Mike is gone and I have no word from him.

question: Al, as far as you're concerned, I'm the Don.
answer: How do I know you haven't gone into business for yourself?

question: You've been through a lot with us so I'm going to give you the truth. Mike knows it was someone within the compound that set him up for that hit. So nobody is to know where he is, not you, not Rocco, not even his brother Fredo. Sorry, Al, I know how you feel about Mike...but he still remembers Tessio. Just a little. What about Kay? Let me try Kay. Kay? Anyone hungry? Hello?
answer: She's gone, Tom.

question: What do you mean gone?
answer: The Barretts from Rubicon Bay came by in a new speedboat. Rocco tried to say she wasn't in, but Kay spotted them and asked if they would take her and the kids for a ride. That was three hours ago.

question: Why didn't someone tell me!
answer: I wanted to tell you alone; your wife doesn't know what's going on.

question: Rocco!
answer: I know. I went down to the Barrett house. But she's gone. They drove her and the kids to North Tahoe airport.

question: Goddamn it, where were you?
answer: I was in my house. Willy tried, but it would have taken some strong-arm to stop her, and he figured you wouldn't want that.

question: Get me a Scotch and water.
answer: She took a flight to San Francisco. We figure she's going to connect to New Hampshire; her parents' place.

question: I can't let him down. All right, let me think a minute.
answer: Me too, Tom?

question: Hiya, Mr. Corleone, I'm Sam Roth. Welcome to the Capri; my brother's upstairs. You wanta take a rest before you see him, or can I get you something, anything at all?
answer: No, I'm fine.

question: This is it! We think it makes Vegas look like the corner crap game.
answer: Very impressive.

question: So, that occurred to me.
answer: This country has had rebels for the last fifty years; it's part of their blood. Believe me, I know... I've been coming here since the twenties; we were running molasses out of Havana when you were a baby. To trucks owned by your father. We'll talk when we're alone. You have to be careful what you say in front of the others... they frighten easy. It's always been that way, most men frighten easy.

question: We're making a big investment in Cuba. That's my only concern.
answer: My concern is that the three million never arrived at Batista's numbered account in Switzerland. He thinks it's because you have second thoughts about his ability to stop the rebels.

question: The money was sent.
answer: Then you have to trace it. Michael, people here look at me as a reliable man. I can't afford not to be looked on as a reliable man. But you know all that; there's nothing you can learn from me. You shouldn't have to put up with a sick old man as a partner.

question: I wouldn't consider anyone else.
answer: Except the President of the United States. If only I could live to see it, kid; to be there with you. How beautifully we've done it, step by step. Here, protected, free to make our profits without the Justice Department, the FBI; ninety miles away in partnership with a friendly government. Ninety miles, just a small step, looking for a man who desperately wants to be President of the United States, and having the cash to make it possible.

question: ... He said he had shot his Grandfather with a gun, and then he died in the garden. And he asked me... he asked me, Tom, if that meant now his father would shoot him out of... revenge. How does a four year old boy learn the word... 'revenge'?
answer: Kay... Kay...

question: What kind of a family is this... are we human beings? He knows his Father killed his Uncle Carlo. He heard Connie.
answer: You don't know that's true. But Kay, just for the sake of an argument, let's assume it is, I'm not saying it is, remember, but... What if I gave you what might be some justification for what he did... or rather some possible justification for what he possibly did.

question: That's the first time I've seen the lawyer side of you, Tom. It's not your best side.
answer: Okay, just hear me out. What if Carlo had been paid to help get Sonny killed? What if his beating of Connie that time was a deliberate plot to get Sonny out into the open? Then what? And what if the Don, a great man, couldn't bring himself to do what he had to do, avenge his son's death by killing his daughter's husband? What if that, finally, was too much for him, and he made Michael his successor, knowing that Michael would take that load off his shoulders, would take that guilt?

question: He's not the same as when I met him.
answer: If he were, he'd be dead by now. You'd be a widow. You'd have no problem.

question: What the hell does that mean? Come on, Tom, speak out straight once in your life. I know Michael can't, but you're not Sicilian, you can tell a woman the truth; you can treat her like an equal, a fellow human being.
answer: If you told Michael what I've told you today, I'm a dead man.

question: When is it finally over? I want it to be over before my baby is born.
answer: I don't know. I hope soon; but it's not over yet, and that's why you and the kids have to come back to me.

question: Mikey. How are you? Hiya, Freddie Corleone.
answer: Mio fratello.

question: What a trip, Jesus Christ, the whole time I'm thinking what if someone knew what I got in here. Oh, 'scuse me.
answer: It's all right. He stays with me all the time.

question: Oh. Mikey, what's up? I'm totally in the dark.
answer: We're making an investment in Havana.

question: Great, Havana's great. Lots of activity in Havana! Anybody I know here. Five-Angels? Anybody?
answer: Johnny Ola... Hyman Roth.

question: I never met them.
answer: Pentangeli's dead. He was ambushed by the Rosato Brothers. Didn't you know that?

question: No. No, I didn't. Who tells me anything? I been kept in the dark so long, I'm getting used to it.
answer: I want you to help me, Fredo.

question: That's what I'm here for.
answer: Tonight I want to relax with you. The Senator from Nevada is here with some people from Washington. I want to show them a good time in Havana.

question: Count on me; that's my specialty.
answer: I'd like to come along. There's been a lot of strain, and I've been cooped up in this room for three days.

question: I do. Play the Bingo game. My sixth sense tells me you have a bag full of money in your hand.
answer: This doubles my investment.

question: Still no word of your courier? We'll find him. But at least this will satisfy our friends here. You've been invited to the New Year reception at the Presidential Home. I understand your brother is here as well; I hope he'll come.
answer: Six million dollars in cash is a high price for a piece of a country in the middle of a revolution.

question: You're a careful kid, and that's good. But look. An international dispatch on the wire service. American journalism, not propaganda. The government troops have all but eliminated the rebels. All but their radio station.
answer: I've read it; I'm pleased that the government is doing so well. As a heavy investor, I'm pleased. How did the doctor find you?

question: Terrible. I'd give twice this amount to take a piss without it hurting.
answer: Who had Frankie Pantangeli killed?

question: Why...the Rosato Brothers.
answer: I know that; but who gave the go ahead. I know it wasn't me...so that leaves you.

question: There was this kid that I grew up with; he was a couple years younger than me, and sort of looked up to me, you know. We did our first work together, worked our way out of the street. Things were good and we made the most of it. During prohibition, we ran molasses up to Canada and made a fortune; your father too. I guess as much as anyone, I loved him and trusted him. Later on he had an idea to make a city out of a desert stop-over for G.I.'s on the way to the West Coast. That kid's name was Moe Greene, and the city he invented was Las Vegas. This was a great man; a man with vision and guts; and there isn't even a plaque or a signpost or a statue of him in that town. Someone put a bullet through his eye; no one knows who gave the order. When I heard about it I wasn't angry. I knew Moe; I knew he was headstrong, and talking loud, and saying stupid things. So when he turned up dead, I let it go, and said to myself There's three million dollars on that table. I'm going to lie down, maybe take a nap. When I wake up, if it's still there, I'll know I have a partner. If it's gone, then I'll know I don't.
answer: How sick do you think the old man is?

question: Does everyone know everyone, or nobody knows nobody. Here, my brother, Michael Corleone... well, you know Senator Geary.
answer: Good to see you, Mike; I'm glad we can spend this time together.

question: This is Senator Payton from Florida; Judge DeMalco from New York... Senator Ream... Mr. Questadt from California, he's a lawyer with the Price-Control Administration. And Fred Corngold of U T&T. Gentlemen... your pleasure? Cuba Libres, Pina Coladas, you name it.
answer: I'll take a Yolanda.

question: Later, later. All those girls look like they're on stilts!
answer: To a night in Havana!

question: Mike said let him gamble. Mike, I got something special up my sleeve for these boys. You ever hear of "Superman?" And I don't mean the comic book.
answer: No.

question: Wait'll you see! Mikey, why would they ever hit poor old Frankie Five-Angels? I loved that ole sonuvabitch. I remember when he was just a 'button,' when we were kids. We used to put bedsheets on our heads, you know, like we were ghosts. An' ole Frankie come peek into our room, we'd jump up, and he'd always pretend like he was really scared. You remember?
answer: It was hard to have him killed.

question: You? What do you mean you, I thought...
answer: It was hard to have him killed.

question: You? What do you mean you, I thought...
answer: It was Frankie tried to have me hit.

question: No. I mean, are you sure?
answer: You know otherwise, Freddie?

question: How is your wife, Fredo...your marriage?
answer: You know her; drives me crazy, one minute she's a popsicle, the next she's all vinegar. Sometimes I think... I think - I should a married someone, like you did. To have kids, to have a family.

question: "Yo soy un hombre sincero..." I am a sincere man, From the land of the palms...
answer: What's that?

question: The song. Are you sincere with me, Fredo?
answer: Sincere. What are you talking about, of course I'm sincere with you, Mike.

question: Then I'm going to confide in you; trust you with something.
answer: Mike, are you crazy, I'm your brother.

question: Tonight we've been invited to a reception at the Presidential Palace; to bring in the New Year. You and I will go in a special car that's being sent. They'll have cocktails... then dinner, and a reception with the President. When it's over, it will be suggested that you take Questadt and his friends from Washington to spend the night with some women. I'll go home alone in the car; and before I reach the hotel, I'll be assassinated.
answer: ...Who?

question: The same man who tried in Nevada... Hyman Roth, not Pentangeli.
answer: But, you told me yourself...

question: It was never Pentangeli... I've always known that. It was Roth all along. He talks to me as a son; as his successor, but the old man thinks he'll live forever.
answer: What do you want me to do?

question: To go tonight, with me, as though we know nothing. I've already made my move.
answer: What is it? Can I help?

question: You are kind. If ever I can do something for you, in return, please come to me. What is it? Why do you come to me? I can give you some money to help you move, is that what you want? It's done then. You won't have to move; I'll speak to him tomorrow morning. I'm sure he's a good-hearted fellow. Once I explain how things are with you, I'm sure he'll take pity on your misfortunes. Don't let it trouble you any more. Guard your health, for the sake of your children. Signore Roberto... The friend of my wife, a poor widow with no man to protect her, tells me that for some reason she has been ordered to move from your building. She is in despair. She has no money, she has no friends except those that live here.
answer: I have already rented the apartment to another family.

question: I told her I would speak to you, that you are a reasonable man who acted out of some misunderstanding. She has gotten rid of the animal that caused all the trouble, so why shouldn't she stay. As one Italian to another, I ask you the favor.
answer: I've already rented it; I cannot disappoint the new tenants. They're paying a higher rent.

question: How much more a month?
answer: Eh... Five dollars more.

question: Here is the six month's increase in advance. You needn't speak to her about it, she's a proud woman. See me again in another six months. But of course, you'll let her keep her dog.
answer: Like hell! And who the hell are you to give me orders. Watch your manners or you'll be on your Sicilian ass in the street there.

question: Kid, where do you live? Say 'bread' in Italian. Go on; how do you say 'bread' in Italian? If you're from the neighborhood, you should know how to say 'bread' in Italian.
answer: What's up?

question: This kid lives around here, but he can't say bread in Italian.
answer: That's 'cause he's Jew. Look at those pregnant lips!

question: Are you a Jewboy? Well, if you're not a Jew, say 'bread' in Italian. See, he can't.
answer: Alright, alright, cut it out. I said cut it out! What's your name?

question: I don't believe it. In our neighborhood, with a name like that!
answer: What are those tools? You work on cars? Maybe I know how you can make a couple of extra bucks working as a mechanic. But you gotta know how to keep your mouth shut, and fer Chrissakes, get rid of that name. I'll call you Johnny Lips. Come on... Bread in Italian is pane. P-A-N-E, pane. Don't forget.

question: Excuse me, I hope I am not a disturbance, Don Corleone.
answer: Yes.

question: What a terrible misunderstanding. Of course, Signora Colombo can stay in the flat. Who were those miserable tenants to complain about noise from a poor animal...when they pay such low rent. Your good heart in helping the poor widow has shamed me, and I want to show that I, too, have some Christian charity. Her rent will remain what it was.
answer: What was that?

question: In fact, reduced, bu five dollars!
answer: I accept your generosity...

question: That's right. The Corleone Family, Senator. We called it, "The Family." At first, like everybody, I was a soldier.
answer: What is that exactly?

question: A button. You know, Senator.
answer: No, I don't know, explain that exactly.

question: When the boss says push the button on a guy, I push the button, see, Senator?
answer: You mean you killed people at the behest of your superiors?

question: That's right, counsellor.
answer: And the head of your family was Michael Corleone.

question: Do you think they have somebody to back up Cicci?
answer: No. But if they do have somebody, you'll do three years for perjury if you give them so much as a wrong middle name. Michael, take the Fifth all the way, that way you can't get into trouble.

question: Al, get me a wet towel. Does Kay know I'm back? Did the boy get something from me for Christmas?
answer: I took care of it.

question: What was it, so I'll know.
answer: A little care he can ride in with an electric motor.

question: Fellas, can you wait outside a minute? Where's my brother?
answer: Roth got out on a private boat. He's in a hospital in Miami. Had a stroke but he's recovered okay. Bussetta's dead.

question: I asked about Fredo?
answer: The new government arrested him, held him for a couple of days with a lot of the other casino people, including Roth's brother, Sam. The American Embassy arranged flights for citizens; I'm not sure, but I think he's somewhere in New York.

question: I want you to reach Fredo. I know he's scared, but have one of our people reach him. Assure him that there will be no reprisals. Tell him that I know Roth misled him.
answer: My information is that Fredo thought it was a kidnapping. Roth assured him nothing would happen to you.

question: They can come in now.
answer: Wait... there's something else.

question: Alright. Go on, tell me.
answer: Kay had a miscarriage; she lost the baby.

question: Was it a boy or a girl?
answer: Mike, at three and a half...

question: What is it, can't you give me straight answers anymore!
answer: It was a boy.

question: And Kay...she's all right?
answer: She took the Senate Investigation worse.

question: Does she blame it on me? The baby?
answer: I don't know.

question: Mom... Mom... It's Michael. How are you, Mom?
answer: I'm alright. Will you stay home for awhile?

question: There are still things I have to do.
answer: Well, we can all have a nice dinner together tonight. How are your eyes?

question: Alright. They bother me once in awhile. Tell me, when Pop had troubles... did he ever think, even to himself, that he had gone the wrong way; that maybe by trying to be strong and trying to protect his family, that he could... that he could... lose it instead?
answer: You talk about the baby. She can have another baby.

question: No, I meant lose his family.
answer: Your family? How can you ever lose your family?

question: Where is this young man? Have him come closer, I can't see very well. What is your name?
answer: Vito Corleone.

question: You took the name of this town, eh? What was your father's name?
answer: Antonio Andolini.

question: Kill him! Kill him!
answer: In the name of my Father, and my Brother...

question: Are you the son of Vito Corleone?
answer: Yes. It was not an alias. GODFATHER was a term of affection, used by his friends, one of respect.

question: I'm sure we all agree with our esteemed colleague. Now, Mr. Corleone, you have been advised as to your legal rights. We have had testimony from a preceding witness who states you are head of the most powerful Mafia family in this country. Are you?
answer: No.

question: This witness has testified that you are personally responsible for the murder of a New York Police Captain in the year 1947 and with him a man named Virgil Sollozzo. Do you deny this?
answer: I deny his every charge.

question: Is it true that in the year 1950 you devised the murder of the heads of the Five Families in New York, to assume and consolidate your nefarious power?
answer: That is a complete falsehood.

question: Is it true that you own a controlling interest in three of the major hotels in Las Vegas?
answer: That is not true. I own some stock in some of the hotels, but only very small amounts. I also own some American Telephone and IBM stock. Senator, I've observed the head of General Motors before a Senate Committee, and his lawyer whispered in his ear. That was not commented upon in the way you have just done.

question: Mr. Corleone, do you have any hotel interests in the state of Arizona? Or any gambling interests in that state?
answer: I do not.

question: Do you have interests or control over gambling and narcotics in the state of New York.
answer: I do not.

question: Ten to one shot, you said. Ten to one shot in my favor, and I lose.
answer: Get a good night's sleep. We got a new suit, new shirt, new tie, and I'm going to shave you myself. Tomorrow we want you to look respectable for fifty million of your fellow Americans.

question: My life won't be worth a nickel after tomorrow.
answer: We have a special home for you for the rest of your life. Nobody gets near you. You're not going any place.

question: Yeah, some deal I made. Some deal. I just wish Mike had took the Fifth.
answer: Why'd you do it, Frankie? After all these years, why'd you turn against him?

question: Alright. I'm going to go outside and talk to Fredo.
answer: I don't have a lot to say, Michael.

question: We have time.
answer: I was kept pretty much in the dark. I didn't know all that much.

question: What about now, is there anything you can help me out with?
answer: I know they get Pentangeli, that's all I know. I didn't know it was a hit. I swear to you I didn't know. Johnny Ola contacted me in Beverly Hills -- said he wanted to talk. He said you and Roth were in on some big deal, and there was a place for me in it if I could help them out. They said you were being tough on the negotiation, and if they had a little bit of help, they could close it fast and it would be good for you.

question: And you believed that story.
answer: He said there was something good in it for me...me on my own.

question: I've always taken care of you.
answer: Taken care of me. Mike, you're my kid brother, and you take care of my. Did you ever think of that. Ever once? Send Fredo off to do this, send Fredo to take care of that... take care of some little unimportant night club here, and there; pick somebody up at the airport. Mike, I'm your older brother; I was stepped over!

question: It's the way Pop wanted it.
answer: It wasn't the way I wanted it! I can handle things. I'm not dumb Christ, not like everyone says. I'm smart; and I want respect.

question: There's nothing more you can tell me about this investigation?
answer: The lawyer; Questadt, he belongs to Roth.

question: You're nothing to me now, Fredo; not a brother, not a friend, I don't want to know you, or what happens to you. I don't want to see you at the hotels, or near my home. When you visit our Mother, I want to know a day in advance, so I won't be there. Do you understand?
answer: Mikey?

question: I never knew no Godfather. I got my own family.
answer: Mr. Pentangeli, you are contradicting your confessions to our investigators; I ask you again, were you a member of a crime organization headed by Michael Corleone?

question: No. I never heard of it. I never heard of nothing like that. I was in the olive oil business with his father a long time ago. That's all.
answer: We have your confession that you murdered on the orders of Michael Corleone. Do you deny that confession and do you know what denying that confession will mean to you?

question: The FBI guys promised me a deal. So I made up a lot of stuff about Michael Corleone. Because then, that's what they wanted. But it was all lies. Everything. They said Michael Corleone did this, Michael Corleone did that. So I said, "Yeah, sure."
answer: Mr. Hagen, would you kindly identify to this committee that gentleman sitting on your right hand?

question: Mr. Hagen, would you kindly identify to this committee that gentleman sitting on your right hand?
answer: Yes, sir. His name is Vincenzo Pentangeli.

question: Is he related to the witness?
answer: He is, I believe, a brother.

question: Sir, I would like you to take the stand.
answer: Sir, the gentleman does not understand English. He would not in any case, take the stand. He came, at his own expense, to aid his brother in his trouble. He is not under any jurisdiction of our government and his reputation in his own country is impeccable.

question: The witness is excused; take him out.
answer: Senator Kane.

question: This meeting is adjourned.
answer: This committee owes an apology!

question: I had no idea...
answer: I wanted to see you before you went back to Nevada. Also, the children - Michael, they're here.

question: Where?
answer: In a minute. They're outside with Esther. I'm very happy for you... I suppose I knew that you're simply too smart for anyone ever to beat you.

question: Why don't you sit down?
answer: I'm not going to stay long; I can't.

question: There are a lot of things I want to talk to you about. Things I've been thinking about -- changes I want to make.
answer: I think it's too late for changes, Michael. I promised myself I wouldn't talk about it and I've gone and spoiled it.

question: Why too late?
answer: Tell me, Michael. What really happened with Pentangeli?

question: His brother came to help him.
answer: I didn't even know he had a brother. And where is he now?

question: On a plane back to Sicily.
answer: And that's all he had to do. Just show his face.

question: That's all. You see, in Sicily, in the old days... there was only one legitimate reason to kill a blood relative... only one. IF he was a traitor.
answer: You would have killed his brother?

question: Kay, you've got it wrong. That kind of thing's all over, I promised you. This was between the two brothers. Years ago Frankie had a young girlfriend; he called her his co-wife. That was his joke, but he meant it. He wouldn't divorce his wife... because she was a great cook. He said he girlfriend made a spaghetti sauce once and it was so terrible he knew he could never marry her. He set her up in a house in Jersey. She had to be faithful... and she had to have kids. And she did, two, a boy and a girl. He had her checked out and watched so she couldn't cheat... but the girl couldn't stand that kind of life. She begged him to let her go. He did. He gave her money and made her give up the kids. Then Frankie took them to Italy, and had them brought up by his brother Vincenzo. Where he knew they'd by safe. When he saw his brother in the hearing room, he knew what was at stake. I don't think Vincenzo would have done it. He loves the kids, too. Omerta, Kay. Honor, silence. It had nothing to do with me. It was between those brothers.
answer: I'll bring the children up now; they want to say goodbye.

question: Kay, I told you...
answer: Goodbye, Michael.

question: I won't let you leave! Christ, do you think I'm going to let you leave.
answer: Michael.

question: No, I don't want to hear anything. There are things between men and women that will not change; things that have been the same for thousands of years. You are my wife, and they are my children... and I love you and I will not let you leave, because you are MINE!
answer: Oh, I do feel things for you, Michael; but now, I think it's pity. For the first time since I've known you, you seem so helpless. You held me a prisoner once; will you try again?

question: If that's what it takes; then yes, I will.
answer: At this moment, I feel no love for you at all. I never thought that could happen, but it has.

question: We'll go back tonight. Bring the children.
answer: You haven't heard me.

question: How can I let you leave; how can I let you take my children away? Don't you know me? You understand, it's an impossibility. I would never let it happen; no, never, not if it took all my strength, all my cunning. But in time, soon, you'll feel differently. You see, you'll be happy that I stopped you. I know you. You'll forget about this; you'll forget about the baby we lost... and we'll go on, you and
answer: The baby I lost...

question: I know what it meant... and I'm prepared to make it up to you. I will make changes; I can. I CAN change; that I have learned, that I have the strength to change... And we have another child, a boy... and you'll forget the miscarriage.
answer: It wasn't a miscarriage. And you with your cunning, couldn't you figure it out! It was an abortion; an abortion, like our marriage is an abortion, something unholy and evil. I don't want your son; I wouldn't bring another of your sons into this world. An abortion, Michael... it was a son, and I had it killed, but this must all end!

question: Michael? It's Connie. I want to stay close to home now, is that alright? Is Kay coming?
answer: No.

question: Michael, Fredo's in the house with Mama. He asked for you, and Tom said he couldn't see you.
answer: Tom is right.

question: Kids, why don't you go outside for a while? I want to talk to you, Michael.
answer: The children can stay.

question: You're going to talk to him now.
answer: Yes.

question: Will you tell him?
answer: I don't know.

question: He's going to try Panama...
answer: They won't take him; not for a million, not for ten million.

question: His medical condition is reported as... "terminal."
answer: He's been dying of the same heart attack for twenty years.

question: That plane goes to Miami...
answer: I want it met.

question: Mike, it's impossible. He'll be met by the Internal Revenue; the Customs Service, and half the FBI.
answer: I don't like it when you use the word impossible; nothing is impossible...

question: Mike, it would be like trying to kill the President; there's no way we can get to him.
answer: I'm surprised at you, Tom. If there's anything certain; certain in life; if history has taught us anything, it's that you can kill... ANYBODY. But perhaps your relucatance is because you've come to tell me that you're moving your family to Vegas, that you've been offered the Vice-Presidency of the Houstan Hotels there. Or weren't you going to tell me at all?

question: Are you so hungry for traitors; do you want to find them everywhere?
answer: They are everywhere!

question: I turned Houstan down; I didn't see why I should tell you about an offer I turned down. Are you sure, Mikey? Are you sure of what we're doing; what we'll gain; what does the family gain? Forget that, Mike; I already know the answer.
answer: I know you do, Tom. Then I can count on you to help me do the things I have to do. If not, call Houstan, and become a Vice-President. Take your family and your mistress and move them to Las Vegas.

question: Why do you hurt me, Michael? I've always been loyal to you.
answer: Good. Then you're staying.

question: I'd like to go outside with him, in the open air.
answer: This room is not bugged.

question: You have guards outside and the electric fence. There's no security reason for not letting us talk in the yard.
answer: Okay.

question: Everything is going to be okay, Frankie, don't worry.
answer: Did my brother go back?

question: Yeah, but don't worry.
answer: He's ten times tougher than me, my brother. He's old-fashioned.

question: Yeah. He wouldn't even go out to dinner. Just wanted to go home.
answer: That's my brother. Nothing could get him away from that two mule town. He coulda been big over here -- he could of had his own Family.

question: You're right.
answer: Tom, what do I do now?

question: Frankie, you were always interested in politics, in history. I remember you talking about Hitler back in '43. We were young then.
answer: Yeah, I still read a lot. They bring me stuff.

question: You were around the old timers who dreamed up how the Families should be organized, how they based it on the old Roman Legions, and called them 'Regimes'... with the 'Capos' and 'Soldiers,' and it worked.
answer: Yeah, it worked. Those were great old days. We was like the Roman Empire. The Corleone family was like the Roman Empire.

question: Yeah, it was once. The Roman Empire... when a plot against the Emperor failed, the plotters were always given a chance to let their families keep their fortunes.
answer: Yeah, but only the rich guys. The little guys got knocked off. If they got arrested and executed, all their estate went to the Emperor. If they just went home and killed themselves, up front, nothing happened.

question: Yeah, that was a good break. A nice deal.
answer: They went home and sat in a hot bath and opened their veins, and bled to death. Sometimes they gave a little party before they did it.

question: Don't worry about anything, Frankie Five-Angels.
answer: Thanks, Tom. Thanks.

question: Here we go; and remember the secret.
answer: Anthony.

question: He's here; we're goin' fishing.
answer: He can't go; Michael wants to take him into Reno.

question: Ah. Okay, kid, you got to go to Reno with your Pop. I'll catch one for you, with the secret.
answer: Hurry, Anthony.

question: Anthony. You've grown so tall... so tall in the last year. You're much taller than me.
answer: I was taller than you when I was fourteen.

question: Sit down. Your Aunt Connie and I waited for you to have some lunch, but now it's all dried out.
answer: I'm not hungry.
